bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, March 7, 1923

div1.p: Noguchi discusses an Ecuadorean fever case that might be yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, March 7, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
N. H. B.
Guayaquil
March 7, 1923
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I am glad you approved of the vaccination record.
We are having some printed.

I have read with interest the report by Dr. Carbo Noboa
of the first case of Weil's disease in Ecuador. It seems that
there was no vomiting in this case, something rather unusual either
in yellow fever or infectious jaundice. However, the patient
suffered intense muscular pains, became yellow, and had hyper-
leukocytosis, all of which constitute evidence of infectious
jaundice, but do not establish the diagnosis absolutely. The mus-
cular pains are usually less intense in yellow fever, and leukopenia
is more usual than hyperleukocytosis. The patient died very
early - 4th or 5th day, I cannot be sure which - which does not
often happen in infectious jaundice. He was from the coast region,
and the residents of the coast are usually immune to yellow fever.
On the whole, I think the case was one of infectious jaundice, al-
though we cannot be absolutely sure. It is unfortunate that there
could be no autopsy.

The two guinea pigs inoculated directly with blood did
not come down, but the author followed my procedure of enriching
the blood by putting it in culture medium and then injecting, even
when the culture is apparently sterile. One of the guinea pigs
inoculated with a microscopically negative 12-day culture came
down with an infection believed to be infectious jaundice.

We shall send Dr. Darling specimens of the material from
the case of yellow fever in Nigeria. By the way, he has some black-
water fever specimens which Dr. Rose sent to him with the request that
he share with me. I hope he has not forgotten me.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Signed) Hideyo Noguchi Dr. F. F. Russell
International Health Board
61 Broadway, New York, N.Y.
